curiosity_phrases: The hammer and plain are said to have been invented by the Romans.
The saw and the set-square is thought to have been invented by Egyptians.
The screwdriver existance can be traced back to the 15th century.
Torque wrench was invented by Conrad Bahr in 1918 while working for the New York City Water Department.
Tool specialization for agriculture may have begun as long as 10000 years ago.
Early hand tools were made with materials, such as, volcanic glass.
Cast metal scissors, similar to those we use today, were first produced in 1761.
Humans have been painting for as long as 30000 years.
Artists used to store their paint in animal bladder.
Acrylic paint only became commercially available in the 50s.
Oil paint takes 2 weeks to dry.
Spray paint was invented in the 1949.
It takes 570 gallons of paint to repaint the White House.
During Roman times, it took 4 million crushed mollusk shells to create one pound of purple pigment.
The color purple was once associated with royalty. At one time only aristocrats could afford the expensive pigment.
In 2004, an artist painted the tip of an iceberg in Greenland bright red, using 3000 liters of a pigment.
Sir Isaac Newton created the color wheel in 1706.
It took Michelangelo 4 years to paint the famous ceiling of the Sistine Chapel in the 16th century.
It took 20 years to restore Michelangelo's Sistine Chapel paiting, in the late 20th century.
The majority of homeowners tend to stay in their homes for around six years before moving.
The term 'housewarming party' comes from the literal tradition that used to occur before electricity.
The creaks in a house often relate to temperature and humidity changes inside it, and not due to its age.
Some 57% of homeowners in America feel their house is still in the 'work-in-progress' stage.
81% of the worldwide DIY market is centered around 8 countries.
36% of Americans took on a DIY project to make their living space more enjoyable.
Interior painting is the most popular DIY job.
The first pencil was invented in England in 1565.
Leonardo da Vinci spent 12 years painting the Mona Lisa’s lips.
The most ancient candles are from China and Japan and were made of whale fat.
The sewing machine was invented in 1790 by Thomas Saint.
The average household uses 14.3 meters of sellotape each year. Only 3.2 meters is used for wrapping presents.
92% of paper crafters create cards more than any other type of project.
In 2010, an American study found that there were 21 million quilters in the USA.
A small amount of super glue is strong enough to lift a 2-ton jeep off the ground.
In the 16th century France, knitting was an occupation for males only.
The first knitting machine was invented in 1589.
Ivory, tortoise shell or bones used to compose the material of knitting needles.
Origami is the art of paper folding, which is often associated with Japanese culture.
Paper was first invented and popularized in China.
Origami was initially used only for religious purposes due to the high cost of paper.
The first book about origami was Sembazuru Orikata (Thousand Crane Folding) written by Akisato Rito and published in 1797.
November 11th is Origami Day!
The fastest time to make 100 origami cranes is 40 minutes 35 seconds achieved by Yoneyama Yuichi.
About 1400 species of grasses exist in the United States.
Grasses make up about 26% of the plant life on earth.
A healthy lawn can increase a house's value by up to 20%.
A 2500 square foot lawn produces enough oxygen for a family of four.
Some of the oldest roofing materials in the world are thatch, clay, and stone.
Clay tiles can be traced all the way back to around 10000 years before christ.
National DIY day is celebrated on the 7th of April.
In the United States, march is the national crochet month.
In the United States, on the 16th of may it's the national drawing day.
In the United States, on the 30th of may it's the national creativity day.
On the 28th of october it's the international artist day.
The global market for home improvement was worth more than 800 billion dollars in 2018.
Single people are less likely to make home improvements than married people.
More than 50% of houses in the US were built before 1980.
In 2018, remodeling a kitchen cost, on average, around 14000 dollars.
England’s King George II died in 1760 after falling off his toilet.
NASA invested more than 20 million dollars in a suction-style toilet for the International Space Station.
The average person uses a toilet about 2,500 times annually.
A toilet uses almost seven gallons of water each time it is flushed.
16th of november id the world toilet day.
A sunflower is not just one flower, but rather thousands of individual flowers.
There are more microorganisms in one teaspoon of soil than there are people on earth.
Music can affect plants growth.
A small amount of baking soda can help you grow sweeter tomatoes, by reducing acidity.
The first greenhouses in history were built in Rome in A.D. 30.
Nearly 1000 jasmine flowers and a dozen of roses go into a single bottle of Chanel No. 5 perfume.
The iris flower is named after the Greek goddess Iris who carries messages of love from heaven to earth.
In ancient Greek mythology, Hyakinthos was the god of spring flowers.
There is a garden in England called The Poison Garden, which is the home of 100 murderous plants.
When a fig is pollinated by a fig wasp, the fig flower traps the wasp and digests the wasp's corpse.
Some types of figs are not considered vegan, as they can contain wasp trails.
The Old English word geard means "fence" and it was the origin of the words "garden" and "yard".
Many religions use gardens as symbols of paradise and immortality.
June 12 is the Red Rose Day.
Wood was the first drawing material used by humans.
The most expensive wood in the world is the African Blackwood.
African Blackwood is used primarily to make luxurious woodwind instruments like clarinets and oboes.
Trees never die of old age. Insects, diseases and people are usually the killers.
White oak is the easiest wood to bend using steam.
The world’s heaviest wood is Australian Bauhinia Red.
Wet wood, unlike dry wood, can conduct electricity.
The heaviest American wood is Lignum Vitae Holywood, particularly rich in Lignin.
Iceland is the country that uses the most electricity annually.
The world's biggest light bulb is located in Edison, New Jersey and it's 14 feet tall.
The average U.S. home uses 11000 kWh of electricity every year.
Electric cars date back as far as 1932.
Coal is the world's biggest dource of rlectricity.
Over 50% of paid electricity is wasted.
LED Lightbulbs use 80% less electricity, than regular lightbulbs.
80% of Americans who have a gym membership don't even use it.
The first car with optional air conditioning was introduced in 1939.
The first air conditioner wasn’t designed for comfort, but rather for avoiding paper to expand.
Herbert Hoover was the first president to have the luxury of having air conditioner.
Air conditioners help to remove allergens and other smaller particles from indoor air.
Home fitness equipment Market is expected to reach 23.27 billion dollars by the year 2025.
Steppers and weight benches have been the most growing home gym equipment to be purchased since 2020, in the UK.
78% of americans have home fitness products.
The first automatic washing machine in 1937.
Protein-based stains such as blood, sweat, and other body fluids, should never be cleaned with hot water on them.
The best thing for removing a fat or oil-based stains is to rub cornflour into the stain.
Soap dates back thousands of years starting with the ancient Babylonians from about 5000 years ago.
Synthetic detergents were invented in the beggining of the 20th century.
The world's first automobile was developed by Carl Benz in 1885.
In 1908, the Model T developed by Henry Ford became the first car available to the masses.
There are an estimated 1.2 billion cars in the world today.
An average car has 30000 parts.
Almost 95% of a car's lifetime is spent parked.
According to an Australian study, white vehicles are 10% less likely to be involved in an accident.
The word "car" comes from the Latin word "carrus", a two-wheeled wagon.
Seat belts were invented by Volvo and were not patented.
Leonardo da Vinci invented the first car in 1478 on paper and in 2004, a replica of the car was crafted.
The small triangle icon next to the fuel icon on the dashboard of a car indicates the gas door side.
Cars are the most recycled consumer product in the world.
Windshield wiper was invented by Mary Anderson in 1903, and was first used in a car in 1922.
Motorola's first product was a car radio.
Most car horns beep in the key of F.
Chalk is made from the bones of ancient sea creatures.
Some towns in Canada use beet juice to melt ice on wintry roads.
Weaving is acknowledged as one of the oldest surviving crafts in the world.
In the early years, cars were seen as the environmentally friendly option because of the waste left behind by horses.
Antilock brakes were invented over 50 years ago.
On the 21th of June it's the international yoga day.
On the 11th of March it's the international plumbing day.
On the 11th of March it's the national worship of tools day.
On the 28th of April it's the workers' memorial day.
Most adults have 32 teeth, which is 12 teeth more than children.
You'll spend on average over two months of your life brushing your teeth.
A tongue print is unique human identifier like a fingerprint.
Henry Seeley invented the first electric iron in 1882.
Thousands years ago in China, pieces of heated metal were used like an iron to uncrease clothes.
Burning coconut shells were used to heat clothes irons instead of charcoal in India.
Nearly 75 percent of all scalding burns in children are preventable.
You should never apply ice or ice water to a burn.
Over one million Earth's could fit inside the Sun.
The Sun is travelling at 220 km per second.
It takes eight minutes for light to reach Earth from the Sun.
A human body contains more than 600 muscles.
A human body contains 206 skeletal bones.
The largest muscle in the human body is the gluteus maximus.
The smallest muscles in the human body are in your inner ear.
Muscles make up about 40 percent of a human total body weight.
Flax is the earliest known natural textile fabric seen to be used in about 5000 BC.
China is the largest maker and exporter of silk in the world.
Microfibre or Ultrasuede was invented over 20 years ago in Japan.
Nylon is a man-made fabric which was first produced in 1938.
The highest quality cotton comes from Eqypt.
Rayon, was the first man-made fiber created in 1910 and it was called 'artificial silk'.
It takes around 700 gallons of water to make a cotton shirt.
Shoes can take up to 1000 years to break down.
70% of the world wears secondhand clothing.
The first pair of Doc Martens Boots were created from old tires.
The skirt is the second-oldest human garment.
Agatha Christie suffered from dysgraphia which meant she could not write legibly. Therefore she dictated all of her novels.
The first published novel 'written' on a word-processor was Len Deighton's 1968 novel Bomber.
John Steinbeck would use up to 60 pencils per day, when writing a book.
The average shower temperature is 108° Fahrenheit.
The amount of water used in a 5 minute shower corresponds to 20 gallons.
The average time spent showering is 8 minutes.
The first commercial dishwasher was invented in 1887.
Motor-powered dishwashers were not invented until 1920.
Contemporary dishwashers use 1/10 water of an average hand wash.
The longest ladder ever measures 135 feets.
The first ladder was depicted in a painting in Spain, dating back at least 10000 years.
A lava lamp is a decorative lamp, invented in 1963 by the British entrepreneur Edward Craven Walker.
Wireless internet was founded in September 1990.
Wristwatches were originally made for women.
The watch worn by the first moon landing astronauts was the Omega Speedmaster.
Most advertisements have watches set to 10:10.
"Moon trees" were grown from seeds taken to the moon during the Apollo 14.
There are 60000 tree species in the world and many are threatened with extinction.
Brazil, Colombia, and Indonesia have the highest number of native tree species.
Different parts of a tree grow at different times throughout the year.
Card games originated in China.
The set of playing cards as we know it today was invented by the French in 1480.
Cheap tractors in the late 1920s helped launch an agricultural revolution.
Crop yield monitors and GPS field navigation first appeared in agriculture in the mid 1990s.
"Green Eggs and Ham" was one of the first GPS receivers developed for farming.
Women make up 30 percent of today's farmers.
Texas has 248809 registered farms, more than any other state in the nation.
One-third of the U.S is covered with trees.
An acre of land is about the same size as a football field.
Cats don't actually meow at each other, instead they use it as a communication tool reserved for humans.
The average life expectancy for a goldfish in the wild is 41 years.
Dogs lick their feet, among other reasons, to help them remember where they have been.
Hamsters' cheek pouches extend all the way down to their hips.
There are around 1500 species of geckos.
Dogs have unique nose prints.
Americans adopt 3.2 million shelter animals every year.
A sofa normally stays in a usable condition for about 8 to 9 years.
Chairs were not commonly used until the 16th century.
Table is derived from the latin word "Tabula" which means "plank" or "flat piece of board".
The Japanese normally sleep on a bed called a tatami, which is like a mat spread out on the floor.
The naturalist Charles Darwin, is known to be the inventor of the modern office chair, with wheels.
The word "chair" came from the Latin word "cathedra" meaning 'sit' and 'down'.
The oldest bookcase in the world is located in Bodleian library at Oxford University.
The oldest bathtub yet discovered dates back to 1500 BC.
The average person spends at least 92 days in the toilet over their lifetime.
In South Korea, there is a Toilet Themed Park, containing toilet art and a museum.
70% of dirt on clothes is invisible.
The first washing machine was called 'Thor'.
World's busiest kitchen, The Sikh Golden Temple in Amritsar, in India, serves on average almost 100000 people per day.
The most expensive kitchen in the world costs 1000000 pounds and took 1 year to be created.
In space, cooking can be tricky, so astronauts use duct tape to stick cooking accessories to work surfaces.
The word "garage" comes from the French word "garer", which means "to shelter".
There are more than 82 million American homes with a garage.
Some music bands that got their start in a garage include the Beatles, Nirvana and Metallica.
Some blue-chip companies that got their start in a garage include Apple, Amazon, Walt Disney, Mattel, and Google.
The first overhead garage door was invented by G. Johnson in 1921.
G. Johnson invented the first automatic door opener in 1926.
60 minutes of solar energy could power the Earth for a year.
Liquified natural gas is chilled to a low negative temperature so it's easy to transport and store.
10 Google searches can power a 60-watt lightbulb.
The word 'energy' is derived from an ancient greek word 'energeia', which means 'state of being at work'.
A single wind turbine can power around 1400 homes.
The world's longest bike was 135 feet long and was built in 2015.
A bicycle can stay upright without a rider as long as it's moving at 8mph or faster.
The largest rideable bicycle has a wheel diameter of 10 ft and was built by Didi Senft from Germany.
Popular bicycle type BMX was created in 1970s as a cheaper alternative to motocross races.
Seven out of eight people in Netherlands that is older than 15 year old has a bicycle.
Over 100 million bicycles are manufactured each year.
Fist Mountain Bikes were made in 1977.
United States is the home of over 400 cycling clubs.
Insects have two antennae and have six legs.
Ants can lift and carry more than fifty times their own weight.
While gathering food, a bee may fly up to 60 miles in one day.
Houseflies find sugar with their feet, which are 10 million times more sensitive than human tongues.
Insects have been present for about 350 million years, and humans for only 300000 years.
There are about 91000 different species of insects in the United States.
The physics of displacement was discovered by Archimedes while he was soaking in a bathtub.
It's against the law for donkeys to sleep in bathtubs in Arizona.
The average bathtub holds approximately 200 Litres of water.
On the Titanic more than 700 third class passengers had to share only two bathtubs.
One leaky faucet in a house that drips once per second can equate to over 180 showers not taken per year.
10% of homes in the U.S. contain leaks that waste a minimum of 90 gallons of water daily.
Early faucets weren’t much more than terra cotta piping leading water into a fountain, but date back to 1700 BC.
The first silver faucets came into use by the Ancient Romans in 1000 BC.
Alfred Moen is credited with inventing the single-handled faucet in 1937.
Having a working smoke detector more than doubles one's chances of surviving a fire.
Cooking equipment is the number-one cause of home fires.
In 1896, Guglielmo Marconi, the father of radio, received a patent for his "wireless telegraph".
In 1919, the first radio station in America began operations in Pittsburgh.
In, 1971 AM-FM radios became standard in new cars.
70% of Americans tune in to radio for 2 hours and 40 minutes each day.
There are approximately 14865 radio stations currently operating in the United States.
First American television station started working in 1928.
The word "Television" was coined in 1900 by Russian scientist Constantin Perskyi.
First TV satellite was launched in 1962.
American homes spend on average 4% on their electricity on powering television.
HD television standards were officially ratified in 1996.
In 1742, at the age of 36, Benjamin Franklin invented the original version of the Franklin Stove.
The first CCTV camera was installed in Germany in 1942.
There are 25 million CCTV cameras in operation worldwide.
Surveillance cameras were not used publicly until 1962 when cameras were installed in Olean, New York to discourage crime.
The first industry to adopt the use of security cameras to prevent theft was the banking industry.
In 1996, Axis Communications released the first IP camera.
Alexander Graham Bell patented his first electric loudspeaker in 1876.
The most common type of loudspeaker today is the dynamic speaker, which was invented in 1925.
The expected life span of cotton fabric is about 100 years.
Zippers were invented in 1893.
Sewing needles found commonly at ancient archaeologist sites were made of bone and ivory, instead of metal.
Sewing was one of the first skills Homo Sapiens learnt.
Metal roofing materials are often lighter in weight than wood shingles.
75% of the homes in North America have asphalt shingles.
Vinyl liner pools are the most common type of swimming pool.
The state with the most swimming pools is California, with 1.1 millions swimming pools.
The world's largest residential pool in the US is in texas carrying over 600000 gallons of water.
President Gerald Ford built the white house pool in 1975.
Pool filters have been around for 105 years.
The most popular swimming pool game is marco polo.
The first tree house can be traced back to ancient civilizations, more than 40000 years ago.
The majority of Indonesian tribes Korowai and Papua still live in tree houses.
In the Middle ages, Franciscan and Hindu monks used tree houses for living in and for meditation.
During the Renaissance period tree houses became very popular in Europe, especially in Italy.
The world's longest fence was established in 1859, in Australia, to protect from wild dogs and rabbits.
The original purpose of the US/Mexico border fence was to help deal with ticks, from mexican catle.
In ancient times, the cheapest alternative to erecting a fence was to dig a deep ditch or trench and fill it with water.
A deep ditch or trench filled with water is called a moat.
Fences can be made of live plants like Kei Apple fances.
In the 1900s, advancements in machinery started to replace shovels.
In 1967, a wooden shovel from approximately 2000 BC was discovered in Turkey.
Throughout history, animal bones, particularly the shoulder blade, have been used like a shovel.
There are examples of screwdrivers being used in both Germany and France during the 15th century.
Screwdrivers were not popular until the industrial revolution.
Archeological evidence shows nails were used in Ancient Egypt around 3400 B.C.
A 2D nail is 1 inch longer.
Penny sizes for nails originated in England where merchants would price their nails according to their length.
The length of nails produced and sold in the United States is measured in "pennies".
To protect against corrosion, nails are often galvanized during production.
A nail-making machine can produce between 500 to 700 nails per minute.
Between the 1790s and the early 1800s, various machines were invented for making nails from iron bars.
In the United States, homeowners spend roughly 30 billion dollars per year on their lawns.
One out of every five homeowners rely on a lawn care professional to take care of their lawn care and landscaping needs.
There's a museum dedicated to the lawn mower, the British Lawnmower Museum, in Great Britain.
The first lawn mower was invented by and Englishman, Edwin Beard Budding and was patented in 1830.
The official demolition of the Berlin Wall began on 1990 and was completed in 1992.
The Great Wall of China is more than 2300 years old and more than 13170 miles long.
Human began building stone walls about 10000 years ago when farming began.
The world's tallest climbing wall is the 121ft Excalibur in the Netherlands.
To produce glass, sand is mixed with lime and soda ash and heated at extremely high temperatures.
As a result of high temperatures, glass can naturally form when sand is struck by lightening.
Glass windows were invented in the 17th century.
The "portland vase" is one of the most valuable glass art pieces in the world.
Glass can be recycled endlessly without losing any quality or purity.
Obsidian, a type of natural glass, can form when hot lava cools quickly after being expelled from a volcano.
Earliest known example of humanity using natural glues comes from 200000 years ago.
One square inch of super glue can hold around one ton.
Prehistoric hunters used natural glue to bind stone arrowheads or axe stones to wood.
First written record of glue comes from the Ancient Egypt.
First commercial glue plant was established in 1690 in Holland.
Glues have natural origin, while adhesives are synthetic.
Yoga is over 5000 years old and is one of the oldest known physical disciplines in the world.
In Sanskrit, the word 'Yoga', means 'union' or 'to unite'.
In the United States, up until 1937, yoga was a male-only practice.
Batteries can be made from food.
Every year, over 15 billion batteries are produced and sold around the world.
Batteries have their own National Day! Celebrated every year on February 18th.
The very first battery was invented all the way back in 1799 by Italian inventor, Alessandro Volta.
6000 years ago, the first stairs were created with tree trunks.
Stairs were installed in The White House in 1948.
In castles, spiral staircases always travel clockwise.
An elephant has climbed the Eiffel Tower.
The practice of giving vases as trophies is one which dates back to Ancient Greece.
The oldest vases which have survived into the present day date back as far as the Bronze Age.
The very first vases we know about weren't decorative at all, but rather used for storage.
The first known revolving wheels used for the creation of vases have been found in Mesopotamia and date back to 3000 BC.
Natural rubber comes from the sap of the Hevea Brasiliensis tree.
Christopher Columbus first witnessed natives in Haiti playing with a rubber ball in 1495.
The first people to use rubber were the natives of Central America, which made rubber balls and boots around 1600 BC.
In the late 18th century, rubber used to erase marks came about by accident.
